Award.AwardTitle: SUPPORT THE COMMITTE ON APPLIED AND THEORETICAL STATISTICS
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Committee on Applied and Theoretical Statistics (CATS) organizes studies and workshops that provide top-quality statistical science advice to help guide major government programs. Some of those programs support the statistical science community, but others do not yet have strong ties to it. CATS activities are carried out by specially appointed committees of experts tailored for each particular activity and in general survey existing research frontiers and recommend best steps for strengthening or applying them; review federal programs and recommend improvements; and/or provide strategic advice to federal programs that depend on the mathematical sciences community.

Overall, the mission of CATS is to manage and reduce uncertainty in national decision-making through the use of modern statistical thinking and to nurture a vibrant statistical sciences research enterprise. The latter goal calls for a statistical sciences discipline that is well-connected with other fields of science, engineering, and medicine; absorbs challenges from those other fields; and maintains a robust core. CATS works to strengthen these attributes of the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public 



 



For
Award #1049906



“SUPPORT
FOR THE



COMMITTEE
ON APPLIED AND THEORETICAL STATISTICS”



Period of Performance: 
04/01/2011 - 03/31/2015 



 



 



The Committee on Applied and Theoretical Statistics
(CATS) of the National Academy of Sciences serves as a source of expert advice
on statistic s and data analytics for a wide variety of federal agencies. That
advice helps to guide federal investments in the sciences, engineering, and
medicine and to incorporate strong statistical insight into public policy. By
providing a link between important national issues and the statistics research
community, CATS also helps to inform that community of emerging challenges and
thus maintain its vigor.



 



The subject grant supported six meetings of CATS, two
associated technical symposia on data science that were open to the general
public, and a workshop on statistical challenges associated with improving the
reproducibility of scientific results. Through its six committee meetings, CATS
also oversaw and initiated additional projects that were funded separately.
Those additional projects included the following:



 




  • A study on the
    mathematical science foundations of verification, validation, and uncertainty
    quantification. (Funded by the Department of Energy and Air Force Office of
    Scientific Research)

  • A study on the
    analysis of massive data. (Funded by the National Security Agency)

  • A workshop on
    observational studies in a learning health system. (Funded by the
    Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute)

  • A workshop on
    training students to extract value from big data. (Funded by the NSF)

  • A workshop on
    image analysis for fisheries stock assessments. (Funded by the National Oceanic
    and Atmospheric Administration)











 



Each of these five activities resulted in a published
report from the National Academies.
